issues.description: The problem statement and UML refer to a Meal class (Meal(String, String[]) with getters), and the solution implements Meal.java accordingly, but the template repository does not provide a Meal class. Instead the template contains an Order.java with the same constructor signature and getters. Additionally, template's Meal.java file is empty. This mismatch (class name/type missing in the template) will confuse students about which class to implement and can prevent compilation of students' code or tests that expect a Meal class.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a Meal class stub in the template matching the problem specification (public class Meal with Meal(String, String[]) constructor and getters for name and ingredients). Either rename the existing Order.java to Meal.java (or remove Order.java) and ensure template's Meal.java contains the proper class; update Main comments if necessary. This aligns the template with the problem statement and the solution, avoiding student confusion and compile errors.

issues.description: The problem statement and the solution refer to the same core concept as the class 'Meal', but the template repository provides this entity under the different name 'Order' (class Order in src/de/tum/cit/ase/Order.java). This creates a direct naming mismatch: students reading the problem expect a Meal class to be present/implemented, but the starter code exposes an Order class with the same shape (name, ingredients). The inconsistency forces students to mentally map 'Meal' ↔ 'Order' (or to rename files/classes), increasing extraneous cognitive load and risking confusion when following instructions and tests that refer to Meal.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the identifier names consistent by aligning the template with the problem and solution. Rename the template's Order class/file to Meal (i.e., file src/de/tum/cit/ase/Order.java → src/de/tum/cit/ase/Meal.java and change class name to Meal). Update any references in the template Main or other files to use Meal. Alternatively, if Order is preferred, update the problem statement and solution to consistently use 'Order' instead of 'Meal'.
